texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: DevConf.CZ 2019  wrapped up last weekend and it was a great event packed with lots of knowledgeable speakers, an engaging hallway track, and delicious food. This was my first trip to any DevConf and it was my second trip to Brno .
texts.text: DevConf.CZ 2019  wrapped up last weekend and it was a great event packed with lots of knowledgeable speakers, an engaging hallway track, and delicious food. This was my first trip to any DevConf and it was my second trip to Brno .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Lots of snow showed up on the second day and more snow arrived later in the week!
texts.text: Lots of snow showed up on the second day and more snow arrived later in the week!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: devconf-snow-small
texts.text: devconf-snow-small

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: First talk of 2019
texts.text: First talk of 2019

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I co-presented a talk with one of my teammates, Nikolai, about some of the fun work we've been doing at Red Hat to improve the quality of the Linux kernel in an automated way. The room was full and we had lots of good questions at the end of the talk. We also received some feedback that we could take back to the team to change how we approached certain parts of the kernel testing.
texts.text: I co-presented a talk with one of my teammates, Nikolai, about some of the fun work we've been doing at Red Hat to improve the quality of the Linux kernel in an automated way. The room was full and we had lots of good questions at the end of the talk. We also received some feedback that we could take back to the team to change how we approached certain parts of the kernel testing.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: devconf-major-nikolai
texts.text: devconf-major-nikolai

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Our project, called Continuous Kernel Integration (CKI), has a goal of reducing the amount of bugs that are merged into the Linux kernel. This requires lots of infrastructure, automation, and testing capabilities. We shared information about our setup, the problems we've found, and where we want to go in the future.
texts.text: Our project, called Continuous Kernel Integration (CKI), has a goal of reducing the amount of bugs that are merged into the Linux kernel. This requires lots of infrastructure, automation, and testing capabilities. We shared information about our setup, the problems we've found, and where we want to go in the future.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Feel free to  view our slides  and watch the video (which should be up soon.)
texts.text: Feel free to  view our slides  and watch the video (which should be up soon.)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Great talks from DevConf
texts.text: Great talks from DevConf

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My favorite talk of the conference was  Laura Abbott's  "Monsters, Ghosts, and Bugs."
texts.text: My favorite talk of the conference was  Laura Abbott's  "Monsters, Ghosts, and Bugs."

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: devconf-laura-abbott
texts.text: devconf-laura-abbott

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's the most informative, concise, and sane review of how all the Linux kernels on the planet fit together. From the insanity of linux-next to the wild world of being a Linux distribution kernel maintainer, she helped us all understand the process of how kernels are maintained. She also took time to help the audience understand which kernels are most important to them and how they can make the right decisions about the kernel that will suit their needs. There are  plenty of good points in my Twitter thread  about her talk.
texts.text: It's the most informative, concise, and sane review of how all the Linux kernels on the planet fit together. From the insanity of linux-next to the wild world of being a Linux distribution kernel maintainer, she helped us all understand the process of how kernels are maintained. She also took time to help the audience understand which kernels are most important to them and how they can make the right decisions about the kernel that will suit their needs. There are  plenty of good points in my Twitter thread  about her talk.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Dan Walsh gave a detailed overview of how to use Podman instead of Docker. He talked about the project's origins and some of the incorrect assumptions that many people have (that running containers means only running Docker). Running containers without root has plenty of benefits. In addition, a significant amount of work has been done to speed up container pulls and pushes in Podman. I took some  notes on Dan's talk  in a thread on Twitter.
texts.text: Dan Walsh gave a detailed overview of how to use Podman instead of Docker. He talked about the project's origins and some of the incorrect assumptions that many people have (that running containers means only running Docker). Running containers without root has plenty of benefits. In addition, a significant amount of work has been done to speed up container pulls and pushes in Podman. I took some  notes on Dan's talk  in a thread on Twitter.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The firewalld package has gained some new features recently and it's poised to fully take advantage of nftables in Fedora 31! Using nftables means that firewall updates are done faster with fewer hiccups in busy environments (think OpenStack and Kubernetes). In addition, nftables can apply rules to IPv4 and IPv6 simultaneously, depeending on your preferences. My  firewalld Twitter thread  has more details from the talk.
texts.text: The firewalld package has gained some new features recently and it's poised to fully take advantage of nftables in Fedora 31! Using nftables means that firewall updates are done faster with fewer hiccups in busy environments (think OpenStack and Kubernetes). In addition, nftables can apply rules to IPv4 and IPv6 simultaneously, depeending on your preferences. My  firewalld Twitter thread  has more details from the talk.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The cgroups v2 subsystem was a popular topic in a few of the talks I visited, including the lightning talks. There are plenty of issues to get it working with Kubernetes and container management systems. It's also missing the freezer capability  from the original cgroups implementation. Without that, pausing a container, or using technology like  CRIU , simply won't work. Nobody could name a Linux distribution that has cgroups v2 enabled at the moment, and that's not helping the effort move forward. Look for more news on this soon.
texts.text: The cgroups v2 subsystem was a popular topic in a few of the talks I visited, including the lightning talks. There are plenty of issues to get it working with Kubernetes and container management systems. It's also missing the freezer capability  from the original cgroups implementation. Without that, pausing a container, or using technology like  CRIU , simply won't work. Nobody could name a Linux distribution that has cgroups v2 enabled at the moment, and that's not helping the effort move forward. Look for more news on this soon.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: devconf-openshift-pun
texts.text: devconf-openshift-pun

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: OpenShift is quickly moving towards offering multiple architectures as a first class product feature. That would incluve aarch64, ppc64le, and s390x in addition to the existing x86_64 support. Andy McCrae and Jeff Young had a talk detailing many of the challenges along with lots of punny references to various "arches". I made a  Twitter thread of the main points  from the OpenShift talk.
texts.text: OpenShift is quickly moving towards offering multiple architectures as a first class product feature. That would incluve aarch64, ppc64le, and s390x in addition to the existing x86_64 support. Andy McCrae and Jeff Young had a talk detailing many of the challenges along with lots of punny references to various "arches". I made a  Twitter thread of the main points  from the OpenShift talk.
